Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Long Term Spatiotemporal Control to Investigate Dynamics in Xenopus Laevis Embryonic Development

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project will develop a system for investigating embryonic development. Specifically the team will develop a system for controlling the chemical environment of nearly microscopic (~1/20th of an inch) samples of embryonic tissues, such as from the African clawed frog, Xenopus laevis, frequently used by biologists. By controlling the region of the tissue that is exposed to different chemicals, and the time for which it is exposed, the research team can gain unprecedented insight into the embryonic development process. Our system will employ sophisticated independent control of five inlet-ports supplying three different fluidic streams. This system will have a wide range of applications for manipulation of the complex chemical environment of engineered tissues. Deliverables include (1) the development of micro-fluidic systems and control systems capable of regulating complex 2D and 3D flow patterns, (2) a novel control algorithm design methodology for dealing with uncertain dynamics, and (3) fluorescent biosensor tools for evaluating control over the microfluidic environment of embryonic tissues.

This project will provide tools for tissue engineers to precisely control chemical stimulation that may be useful for creating new tissues for long term future clinical application. The work will combine techniques that previously have been successfully implemented in microfabrication and automatic control of disk drives. These tools may be used to create complex patterns of chemical stimulation to growing cells for manufacturing of engineered tissues. Dissemination of our results will also lead to new devices with increased accuracies, reliability, and functionality for commercial and basic science applications. In addition, this project will train undergraduate and graduate students to become leaders in science and industry in transdisciplinary fields including dynamic systems/controls, biology, microtechnology, and engineering. The team will also reach out to underrepresented K-12 students in academically challenged neighborhoods to build their knowledge and their interest in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh with collaborators at Carnegie Mellon University and Tufts University have extended engineering applications of microfluidics to investigate and expose principles of biological tissue self-assembly. In much of the literature, microfluidic systems are used simply to investigate the timing of 'on-off' switches, for instance, applying a simple step function of stimulus and resolving the time-course of the response. This works extremely well for investigating the control-network of intracellular signaling within a single cell. However, within complex tissues there are often multiple signal transmission pathways that can connect the stimulated cell to more distant responder cells. The challenge to understanding signal transmission in complex tissues is then to dissect the pathways responsible for the initial detection of a stimulus from the pathways responsible for their transmission and their actuation. Thus, our interest in microfluidic control stems from the precise control of both the chemical microenvironments of the three-channel microfluidic system and their potential to allow us to separate the intracellular detection pathways from transmission and actuation pathways.

The project has succeeded in using precise microfluidic control to expose a novel mechanism of propagating morphogenetic signals through a tissue and in using microfluidic control to microdissect tissues via spatial and temporally regulated decellularization. Ongoing studies by our group identified a purinergic signaling pathway that induces a rapid mechanical response in response to exposure to adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and uridine triphosphate (UTP). Using microfluidics we have confirmed those suspicions that the ATP stimulus was transmitted through non-exposed cells to induce distant cells to contract. ATP stimulation in a narrow stream of 2 to 3 cell diameters can stimulate contraction nearly 10 cells away from the stream. Microfluidic control allowed us to design a powerful multistep protocol that combines control experiments with experimental tests on the same tissue explant. The possibility that mechanical contraction of cells might play a role in transmitting signals led us to devise a series of experiments combining ATP-stimulation, myosin II inhibition, and gap junction inhibitors to expose this potential role and contrast it to the role of gap junction signaling. We found that transmission of the ATP stimulus signal through non-exposed cells requires cell contractility.

To investigate the processes that guide collective movements of multiple cell layers we have focused on developing a novel microfluidic technique capable of producing complex patterns of multicellular structures. We call this technique "3D tissue-etching” by analogy with silicon micromachining techniques used to fabricate 3D structures in the MEMS field where complex 3D structures are built by successive steps to remove material from a monolithic solid. We use tissue etching to shape a complex multilayered embryonic tissue and explore the dynamic collective responses of epithelial and mesenchymal cells in a single tissue. We use a custom-designed microfluidic control system to deliver a range of tissue etching reagents (detergents, chelators, proteases, etc.) over tissues microsurgically isolated from embryos of the African claw-toed frog Xenopus laevis. Xenopus embryos have been used extensively to elucidate genes important in morphogenesis and here provide a model for collective migration of a complex tissue. Using etching we produce free-edges of epithelial cells over mesenchymal cells and free-edges of mesenchymal cells.
